questions.text: Which of the following would you first advise a patient with a large thyroid swelling on their first visit?
questions.solution:
Assessing the biochemical function of the thyroid i.e. thyroid function test (TFT) is the first investigation done in any thyroid condition.

Evaluation of any thyroid disease should begin with the assessment of TSH, T3, and T4. TSH is the only test necessary in most patients with thyroid nodules that clinically appear to be euthyroid.

Modalities for evaluation of thyroid swelling include:

  • Laboratory evaluation
    • TSH
    • T3
    • T4 
  • Thyroid imaging
    • Ultrasound
    • Radioisotope scanning
    • CT/MRI
  • Biopsy techniques
    • Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNA)
    • Tru-cut/core-needle biopsy

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia with leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). CLL is a tumor of mature B cells and the most common leukemia in adults.

Patients with CLL present with nonspecific symptoms like easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are present in about 50-60% of cases. There is also increased susceptibility to infections due to disruption of immune processes.

The peripheral smear, as shown in the image below, typically shows small round lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm (indicated by arrows). Some of these cells get disrupted while preparing the smear; these cells are called smudge cells (indicated by arrowheads).

Other options:

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic lymphoma (ALL) is a tumor of immature B or T cells and the most common leukemia in children. The peripheral blood smear shows lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm.

Option C: Multiple myeloma is a neoplasm of plasma cells. It is also typically associated with punched-out bony lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal. Bone marrow aspirate shows plasma cells with multiple nuclei and prominent nucleoli. Serum protein electrophoresis shows a spike of M protein (monoclonal immunoglobulin).

Option D: Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a hyperviscosity syndrome caused due to excess amounts of monoclonal IgM secreted by plasma cells. It is a type of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, with bone marrow aspirate showing small lymphocytes with variable degrees of plasma differentiation.

Related Pearl: Cytogenetic Translocation and Associated Oncogenes Often Seen in Lymphoid Malignancies

questions.text: Modified Mallampati grading is used in the assessment of _______.
questions.solution:
The Modified Mallampati classification is used in the assessment of difficult airway.

Modified Mallampati grading:

  • Class 0: Ability to see any part of the epiglottis upon mouth opening and tongue protrusion
  • Class I: Soft palate, fauces, uvula, pillars visible
  • Class II: Soft palate, fauces, uvula visible
  • Class III: Soft palate, base of uvula visible
  • Class IV: Soft palate not visible at all

Test: The assessment is performed with the patient sitting up straight, mouth open and tongue maximally protruded, without speaking or saying “ahh.”

Classes 3 and 4 are difficult intubation situations.

Percentage of glottic opening (POGO score) and Cormack–Lehane (CL) classification is broadly used to describe laryngeal view during direct laryngoscopy.

Seshagiri Rao Mallampati (1941 – ) is an Indian-origin American anesthesiologist. The ‘original’ Mallampati scoring system had only three stages and was published in 1985.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the dermatology department with lesions over the skin as shown below.  On examination, the lesions were dry, scaly, and slightly shiny, with moderately diminished sensation. Which type of leprosy do these lesions indicate?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing of moderately hypoesthetic annular plaques with punched-out lesions is suggestive of the borderline-borderline (BB) type of leprosy.

BB is the most immunologically unstable type of the borderline spectrum. Patients in BB will shift towards lepromatous or tuberculoid types quickly. 

Skin lesions in BB are in the form of infiltrated papules, plaques, nodules. The characteristic lesions of BB leprosy are annular plaques with well-demarcated, punched-out inner margins and a sloping outer margin. They appear as large plaques with islands of clinically normal skin within the center, giving rise to Swiss cheese appearance. 

 

Inverted saucer lesions are raised lesions with ill-defined borders that are mainly seen in borderline lepromatous (BL) type of leprosy lesions as shown below.

Pure neuritic leprosy (PNL) is a rare variant of leprosy. It is characterized by isolated involvement of peripheral nerve trunks in the absence of skin lesions.

Patients with PNL present with nerve thickening pain, tenderness, and sensory-motor impairment. Sensory neuropathies like loss of heat and pain sensitivities are more predominant in PNL. they most commonly present with mononeuritis.

questions.text: Autoclaving and microwaving are done for which of the following category of wastes?
questions.solution:
Autoclaving and microwaving are done for recyclable contaminated waste. It is disposed off in a RED bag.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

The changes as per the new Biomedical waste management (amendment) rules, 2018 have been included in the above table and highlighted in green.

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)  

Type of Waste

Human anatomical waste

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial

Autoclaving/Microwaving/ Hydroclaving

Later - Shredding/mutilation

Pyrolysis or for energy recovery.
In absence of above facilities, shredding
or mutilation or combination of
sterilization and shredding.

(Autoclave safe plastic bags used)

live or

human and animal cell

of biological, residual
toxins, dishes and
devices used for
cultures.

and used or discarded
disinfectants.

laboratories and floor
washings, cleaning,

etc.

liquid waste shall be pre-treated before
mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable Contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes(without needles and fixed needle syringes), vaccutainers with needles cut and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by -  Shredding/mutilation

And later -  Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/Road making

Not to be sent to landfill

(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/Mutilation/
Encapsulation

  Blue  
(Puncture proof and leak proof containers with blue colored marking)

Type of Waste

Glassware

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic Body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

Later - Recycling

 Note: Ash from incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: You were posted for screening of deafness in school children under your primary health center. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done for deafness in school children is prescriptive screening. 

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined primarily for their own benefit. It may lead to the early identification of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to decline the disease progression.

Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. Examples of prescriptive screening are:

  • Screening of hemolytic disease in newborns
  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of bacteriuria in pregnancy

Other options:

Option A - Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are screened for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community. Hence, reduces mortality associated with the disease. Examples of prospective screening are:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the citizens
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever

Option B - Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination, to a large population at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population.

Option D - Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most effective screening tests.

Example: Screening for diabetes in the other members of a family for a detected diabetes case since these diseases get aggregated in families.

questions.text:
Arrange the following colour codes used in triage in the increasing order of priority starting with the least priority.
  1. Red
  2. Black 
  3. Yellow
  4. Green
questions.solution:
Option C is the correct sequence of triage color coding.

2 Black
4 Green
3 Yellow
1 Red

 

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment. Higher priority is given to victims whose prognosis would be good with simple medical care. Lower priority is given to moribund patients who would have questionable benefits even with medical attention.

Note:

In the event of a disaster, mass casualty or epidemic, hospitals face a significant demand or a surge for healthcare services that often outpaces the supply of available resources. Reverse triage is implemented during these surge periods.

By identifying and discharging low-risk patients, reverse triage allows faster and more efficient treatment of critically ill patients. It also helps minimize mortality and morbidity for the greatest number of patients while treating the largest number of patients in the shortest period of time.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A young male who had a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. A plain radiograph of his hip was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?

choices.text: Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels
Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of posterior hip dislocation. In this condition, the leg will be in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. 

Posterior hip dislocation is the commonest type of hip dislocation accounting for about 80%  of the cases. It is commonly seen following dashboard injuries. The patient presents with flexion, adduction, and an internal rotation deformity.

Radiological findings include femoral head lying above and behind the acetabulum, femoral head appearing smaller than normal, lesser trochanter not visualized as the thigh is internally rotated and the femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen

Sciatic nerve injury is seen in 10-20 % of cases with posterior hip dislocation. It is usually a neuropraxia type of injury and resolves spontaneously. The femoral artery pulsation is usually felt against the neck of the femur. Due to the posterior dislocation of the hip joint, the femoral vessels fall backwards and the pulsation of the femoral artery cannot be felt. This is called the vascular sign of Narath.

Anterior hip dislocation is less common than posterior hip dislocations and accounts for about 10-20% of all hip dislocations. This injury is usually sustained following a high-energy accident. The affected limb in this condition will be abducted, externally rotated, and slightly flexed.

Note: Although, vascular injuries are seen in posterior dislocations as well, they are most likely with anterior dislocation. This is because of the femoral artery lying anterior to the head

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation
Prevalence Less common Most common
Type of injury Deceleration injury/ Fall from height Dashboard injury
Attitude of the limb Flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (FADIR)
Length of the limb Lengthened Shortened
Radiological findings
  • Femoral head may be seen inferior to the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised
Nerve injured  Femoral nerve  Sciatic nerve

questions.text: Patients with which of the following tumors are best treated with radiotherapy?
questions.solution: Patients diagnosed with seminoma are best treated with radiotherapy, as it is a highly radiosensitive tumor.

questions.text: In which condition  is the X ray given below seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows folds that run horizontally around the entire circumference of the oseophageal lumen, which is called a feline esophagus and is seen in reflux esophagitis. 

Feline oesophagus is also known as oesophageal shiver, refers to the transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower oesophagus on a double contrast barium swallow. The appearance is almost always associated with active gastroesophageal reflux and is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae with resultant shortening of the oesophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen.

Radiologic features: The folds are 1-2 mm thick and run horizontally around the entire circumference of the oseophageal lumen. The findings are transient, seen following reflux and not during swallowing. The appearance is confined to the distal two-thirds of the thoracic oesophagus.

It can also be seen in hiatus hernia and eosinophilic oesophagitis (wherein the folds will be permanent and be associated with strictures).

 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the clinic with significant astigmatism. The following finding is noted on closer examination. What is the ideal course of management?
questions.solution:
In a patient with a progressive pterygium causing astigmatism, excision of the pterygium along with conjunctival autograft is the preferred management.

Pterygium is a wing-shaped fold of the conjunctiva extending into the cornea. It is commonly seen in people who live in hot climates and in those who work outdoors.

Clinically the patient may present with symptoms such as: 

  • Cosmetic complaints
  • Foreign body sensation and irritation
  • Defective vision/astigmatism when the pterygium extends into the pupillary area
  • Diplopia

Medical management includes tear substitutes, topical corticosteroids, and sunglasses. Surgical management is preferred in patients with significant cosmetic defects, visual impairment, and other such complications.

Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft is the preferred technique for most pterygiums. In case of recurrent or large pterygium, surgical excision with amniotic membrane graft and mitomycin C is preferred.

questions.text: Insulin release due to the closure of K+ channels is seen with?
questions.solution:
Repaglinide acts by increasing insulin secretion by blockage of ATP sensitive K+ channels of the beta cells of the pancreas.

When ATP sensitive K+ channels are blocked ,it will lead to depolarisation of beta cells and then release of insulin.

questions.text: During a cricket match, a batsman controls his urge to urinate as he is unable to take a break in-between. While batting, he suffers a sudden blow as the ball hits him in the suprapubic region. He presents to the emergency department with severe hypogastric pain and the inability to pass urine. He collapses suddenly during the examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Pubic diastasis with bulbar urethra rupture

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of injury to a full bladder, inability to pass urine, and syncope are suggestive of intraperitoneal rupture of the bladder.

Bladder rupture can be of two types:

  Extraperitoneal rupture Intraperitoneal rupture
  More common (80%)  Less common (20%)
Cause
  • Penetrating trauma
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Surgical damage
  • Associated with proximal urethral injury
  
  • Direct blow or fall on a distended bladder
Clinical features
  • Pelvic urinoma (encapsulated collection of extravasated urine) is seen
  • Blood at the tip of the meatus
  • Sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium
  • Syncope
  • Peritonitis
 
Treatment
  • Catheter drainage for 7–10 days
  • Laparotomy
  • Repair of bladder
  • Bladder drainage
 


Pubic diastasis refers to the separation of the pubic symphysis without concomitant fracture. Pubic diastasis with bulbar urethra rupture usually occurs due to straddle injury and presents with blood at the tip of the meatus.

questions.text: The base of heart is formed by:
questions.solution:
The base of the heart is formed mainly by the left atrium

The base of the heart is a quadrilateral directed posteriorly. It is made of:

  • The left atrium mainly
  • Small part of the right atrium
  • Proximal parts of superior vena cava, inferior vena cava and pulmonary veins

The base of the heart lies at the level of T5-T8 vertebrae in the supine position.

The apex of the heart is formed by the left ventricle in the 5th intercostal space.

questions.text: Chikungunya virus is transmitted by ________
questions.solution:
Chikungunya is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes.

Chikungunya presents with sudden onset of fever, crippling joint pain, lymphadenopathy, and conjunctivitis. The fever is typically biphasic with a period of remission after 1–6 days. 

 

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

Arthropod Disease transmitted
Anopheles mosquito Malaria, Filariasis
Culex mosquito Bancroftian filariasis, Japenese encephalitis, West nile fever, Viral arthritis
Aedes mosquito Yellow fever, Dengue, Chikungunya, filariasis, zika
Mansoni Mosquito Filariasis, Chikungunya
Housefly Typhoid and paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly Kala-azar, oriental sore, Oroya fever, Sandfly fever
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus, chiggerosis, hymenolepis diminuta
Black fly Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug Chagas disease
Hard tick (Ixodes species) Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, viral hemorrhagic fever,(e.g. Kyasanur forest disease), tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, lyme disease
Soft Tick (Argas species) Q fever, relapsing fever
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus, Rickettsial pox
Itch mites Scabies
Cyclops Guinea-worm disease, fish tapeworm (D. latum)
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in type 2 respiratory failure?
questions.solution:
Type 2 respiratory failure is characterized by low pO2 and high pCO2.

Acute respiratory failure refers to acute impairment in gas exchange between the lungs and the blood causing hypoxia with or without hypercapnia. The various types are classified based on the abnormalities in respiratory function and are given below:

  • Type 1 is due to a diffusion defect at the alveolar level, leading to alveolar oxygenation defect or hypoxia (low pO2) with normal or low pCO2, but not high pCO2. There is an increased alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient (high pAO2-paO2) and often a ventilation-perfusion(V/Q) mismatch; the volume of air flowing in and out of the lung is not matched to the blood flow to the lung.
  • Type 2 is due to a ventilation defect, leading to inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively . This leads to hypoxia (low pO2) with hypercapnia (high pCO2). As diffusion is not defective, the alveolar-arterial gradient is unaffected with both low pAO2 (alveolar) and low paO2 (arterial).
  • Type 3 results from lung atelectasis commonly during the perioperative period.
  • Type 4 is due to the hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles secondary to shock.

Related Pearl: Types of respiratory failure

 

Type Name Mechanism Associated conditions
I

Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure

(Low paO2 only)

 Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology.
  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Lung injury and alveolar hemorrhage
  • Pneumonia
  • Acute severe asthma
  • Other causes: Sepsis, gastric aspiration, near-drowning, multiple blood transfusions, and pancreatitis.
II

Hypoxemia with hypercapnia

(Low paO2, High PaCO2)

 Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively.
  • Respiratory center: brainstem injury, severe hypothyroidism, sleep apnoea, sedative drug overdose.
  • Chest wall and neuromuscular: Kyphoscoliosis, ankylosing spondylitis, myasthenia gravis, motor neuron disease, myopathy, fatigue.
  • Lung: COPD, pleural pathology, foreign body obstruction.
III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.
IV Shock Results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock Cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: Which of the following types of morbidly adherent placenta is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows placental tissue invading the myometrium of the uterus suggestive of placenta increta. 

Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. It is of three types:

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa. 

Based on the adherence of placental lobules, all three types of morbidly adherent placenta can be:

  • Total - involving all lobules of the placenta 
  • Focal - involving a single lobule or part of a lobule of the placenta

Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via C-section and peripartum hysterectomy.

questions.text:
Which of the following modifications occur posttranscriptionally to produce a mature eukaryotic mRNA?
  1. Capping
  2. Polyadenylation
  3. Phosphorylation
  4. Trimming
  5. Splicing
  6. Hydroxylation
questions.solution:
Capping, polyadenylation, and splicing are the modifications that occur posttranscriptionally to produce a mature eukaryotic mRNA. Phosphorylation, hydroxylation, and trimming are modifications that occur posttranslationally.

A mature eukaryotic mRNA is formed after the pre-mRNA components of the heterogenous nuclear RNA (hnRNA) undergo the following posttranscriptional modifications in the nucleus:

  1. Addition of a 5′ cap: A 7-methylguanosine is attached to the 5′ terminal end of the mRNA via a 5′-to-5′ triphosphate linkage. This stabilizes the mRNA and allows initiation of translation.
  2. Addition of a 3′-poly-A tail: The poly-A tail is added by the nuclear enzyme, polyadenylate polymerase, after clevage of the polyadenylation signal sequence (AAUAAA) found near the 3′ end of the mRNA. This terminates eukaryotic transcription. Furthermore, it stabilizes the mRNA, allows it to exit from the nucleus, and helps in translation.
  3. Splicing: This is the process of removing introns (intervening sequences that do not code for proteins) and joining exons (the coding or expressed sequences), carried out by the spliceosome. Alternative splicing occurs in different tissues to produce varied number of proteins from a limited set of genes.

Protein coding RNA

Non Protein coding RNA

mRNA

Ribosomal RNAs (rRNA)

Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs)

Transfer RNAs (tRNA)

Small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs)

Micro and silencing RNAs (miRNAs and siRNAs)

questions.text: The sequence of oxygenated blood flow from the placenta to the fetal heart is  ________.

choices.text: Umbilical artery → inferior vena cava → ductus venosus → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical artery → superior vena cava → right atrium → ductus arteriosus → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus arteriosus → superior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium

questions.solution:
The sequence of oxygenated blood flow from the placenta to the fetal heart is umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior venacava → right atrium → left atrium.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min.

questions.text: A patient is on magnesium sulfate therapy post-cesarean section for preeclampsia.  During her assessment after the 3rd maintenance dose, she has a respiratory rate of 8/min, a random blood glucose level of 240 mg/dL, oliguria, and a bilaterally absent knee reflex. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to manage this case?

choices.text: Stop magnesium therapy and give IV calcium gluconate
Stop magnesium therapy and give oral calcium gluconate
Give half dose magnesium therapy and IV calcium gluconate
Skip the next maintenance dose and follow up

questions.solution:
The next step in this patient with magnesium sulphate (MgSO4) toxicity is to stop magnesium therapy and give IV calcium gluconate.

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4–7 mEq/L. MgSO4 has to be administered up to 24 hrs after the last seizure (in postpartum seizure) or delivery, whichever is later.

Signs suggestive of magnesium toxicity include:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate <12/min
  • Urine output <30 mL/h
  • Chest pain and heart block 
  • Visual changes, flushing, muscle paralysis, and drowsiness

It is treated by stopping magnesium therapy and giving slow IV calcium gluconate 10 mL (10% solution) infusion. Fluid loading and forced diuresis are done and estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels. Before administering the maintenance dose of MgSO4, the above signs are checked. IM injections of magnesium sulfate are continued only under the following conditions:

  • The patellar reflex is present
  • Respiration is not depressed
  • Urine output >30 mL/h

 The two commonly used MgSO4 regimens are described below: 

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Intramuscular (Pritchard)

4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 minutes, followed by 10 g (50%) deep IM (5 g in each buttock)

5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock

Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)

4 g IV slow over 15–20 minute

1–2 g/h IV infusion

questions.text: The following image shows the sequence of propulsion of a bolus in the gut by means of peristalsis. Which of the following substances is responsible for the configuration of the segment of the gut marked as '2'?
questions.solution:
The given configuration of the segment marked by '2' is due to the vasoactive intestinal peptide being responsible for a state of relaxation of this part of the gut. 

The above image shows peristalsis. It is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. The given segment of relaxation is an anterograde segment that moves from an oral to a caudal direction. 

Stretching of the gut wall releases serotonin and activates the cholinergic neurons present in the myenteric plexus. Cholinergic neurons passing in an anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus. Cholinergic neurons passing in a retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

The following image shows the events as described.

 

Note:

In achalasia cardia, there is a defective release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is Whipple's procedure. 

The following structures are removed during Whipple’s procedure:

  • Distal stomach
  • Duodenum
  • Proximal jejunum
  • Head of the pancreas
  • Gallbladder
  • Common bile duct (CBD)
  • Regional lymphatics

The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when:

  • The entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  • Tumour encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach
  • A clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy

Other options: 

Option B: In Billroth II loop gastrojejunostomy, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum. It helps to re-establish gastrointestinal continuity following antrectomy for complicated peptic ulcer disease.

Option C: Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder. Following this, a Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is mobilized and anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

The Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is shown in the image below.

Option D: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is used as bariatric surgery where a small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature of the stomach and a roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum) is created by anastomosing the proximal jejunum to the gastric pouch and, a shorter biliary/biliopancreatic limb of 30 - 50 cm (consisting duodenum and proximal jejunum) is anastomosed to the roux limb via side to side jejunojejunostomy.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument used in mastoidectomy:
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mollison’s mastoid retractor. It is used in mastoidectomy procedures to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.

Other options:

Option B: Lempert’s endaural retractor is used for an endaural approach to ear surgery. It has two lateral blades that retract the flaps and a third central blade with holes. The central blade retracts the temporalis muscle and can be fixed to the body of the retractor by its holes.

The image of Lempert’s endaural retractor is given below.

Option C:  A myringotome is a sharp surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum during myringotomy. The image is given below.

 

Option D: Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor(shown below) is used in mastoidectomy and is similar to Mollison’s retractor.

questions.text: Which of the following parameter is used in the calculation of the pearl index?
questions.solution:
The parameter used in the calculation of the pearl index is total accidental pregnancies.

Pearl Index:

  • The pearl index is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

It can be calculated as follows.

  • The total accidental pregnancies must include all pregnancies irrespective of the outcome(live births, still-births or abortions).
  • The total months of exposure is obtained by deducting 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

questions.text: Which of the following is mainly associated with cANCA?
questions.solution:
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis( Wegner’s granulomatosis) is mainly associated with cANCA.

The antineutrophilic antibodies (ANCA) can be further classified into two major categories:

  • Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)- associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis).
  • Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)- associated with microscopic polyangitis, Churg-Strauss syndrome and crescentic glomerulonephritis.

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3

 Myeloperoxidase

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining

questions.text: According to sigmund freud in the interpretation of dreams, which of the following terms refers to the representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected with the idea or object being represented?
questions.solution:
Symbolism refers to the representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected with the idea or object being represented.

According to the Interpretation of dreams written by sigmund freud, dreams represent unconscious wishes or thoughts which are not accepted by the conscious mind. They manifest through the following mechanisms:

  • Symbolism: Representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected. 
  • Displacement: Transfer of mental energy from one object to a substitute or symbolic representation of the object. 
  • Condensation: Mechanism by which multiple unconscious wishes combine into a single image. Converse to it is called irradiation or diffusion, where, one unconscious wish gets distributed into multiple images. 
  • Projection: Attributing one’s own unacknowledged feelings to others. 
  • Secondary elaboration: Process by which the ego organizes illogical, bizarre and absurd images into a more coherent form in dreams. 

 

Related Pearl: Contributions by Sigmund Freud

Contributions of Sigmund Freud to the field of psychiatry

  • Free association
  • Interpretation of dreams
  • Psychoanalysis
  • Psycho-sexual development 
  • Psychodynamic theory 
  • Topographic theory of the mind-unconscious, preconscious, conscious
  • Structural theory of mind- id, ego, superego
  • Cocaine in psychiatry

questions.text: You are on duty in the gastroenterology department as a second-year resident, evaluating patients for upper and lower gastrointestinal lesions. What will be your diagnosis of the following images?

choices.text: A- Barrett's esophagus, B- Mallory Weiss tear
A- Mallory Weiss tear, B- Barrett's esophagus
A- Crohn’s Disease, B- Ulcerative Colitis
A- Ulcerative Colitis, B- Crohn’s Disease

questions.solution:
Image A shows ulcerative colitis and image B shows Crohn's disease.

The given image A shows continuous involvement of mucosa with no normal mucosa in between, which indicates ulcerative colitis. 

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

Colonoscopy shows loss of typical vascular pattern, granularity, friability, and ulceration involving the distal rectum, extending proximally in symmetric, continuous, and circumferential patterns. Fistula is not a complication of ulcerative colitis. 

Image B shows a cobblestone appearance seen in Crohn's disease. Normal mucosa in between the ulcers leads to this appearance. Fine granular mucosa is the earliest barium enema finding in Ulcerative colitis. Fistula is seen with Crohn’s disease.

Crohn's disease may occur in any area of the GI tract, but the most common sites involved at presentation are the terminal ileum, ileocecal valve, and cecum. It is associated with smoking.

 In Crohn's disease, the following are seen:

  • Aphthous ulcers - Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers - Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance - Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas

Other options:

Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the mucosal lining of the swallowing tube that connects the mouth to the stomach (esophagus) becomes damaged by acid reflux, which causes the lining to thicken and become red. It is associated with an increased risk of developing esophageal cancer.

 

Mallory Weiss tear is due to a longitudinal tear in mucosa or submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction. It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or staining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

Related Pearl: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)

 

  Crohn's disease Ulcerative colitis
Age of onset  2nd-4th decades & 7th-9th decades 2nd-4th decades & 7th-9th decades 
Most common presentation Ileocolitis with rectal sparing Proctitis (rectum)
Protective factors  None 

Smoking 

Appendicectomy
Risk factors

OCP

Smoking

Antibiotic during first year of life 

α-Methyldopa

Antibiotic during first year of life
T cell involved TH1  TH2
Gross findings/ endoscopic findings

Transmural involvement

Segmental involvement

Skip lesions

Cobblestone appearance

Creeping fat

Longitudinal ulcers

Mucosal involvement 

Continuous involvement

Pseudopolyps 

Backwash ileitis 

Collar button ulcers
Earliest finding Aphthous ulcer Erythematous mucosa with a fine granular surface
Microscopic findings 

Deep, knife-like ulcers

Granulomas

Pyloric metaplasia  

Superficial, broad-based

Cryptitis and crypt abscess 

 
Complications 

Fistulas 

Strictures

Hemorrhage

Toxic megacolon
Recurrence after resection

Common

Uncommon, curative after resection
Radiological findings 

Aphthous ulcer

Rose thorn appearance

Mucosal granularity

Lead pipe appearance
Extraintestinal manifestations

Episcleritis, uveitis 

Migratory polyarthritis

Ankylosing spondylitis, sacroiliitis

Erythema nodosum

Pyoderma gangrenosum- MC in UC

Primary sclerosing cholangitis- MC in UC

Renal Calculi- MC in CD

questions.text: The best treatment for anemia in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients is ______
questions.solution:
Human recombinant erythropoietin eg: darbepoetin is the best treatment for anemia in CKD (chronic kidney disease) patients.

The anemia of CKD is primarily due to decreased erythropoietin production. Hence, erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (ESAs, eg, epoetin and darbepoetin) become the mainstay of treatment in anemia of CKD.

However, iron stores must be adequate to ensure a response to ESAs. Since iron deficiency is common in CKD patients, iron therapy is a crucial initial step in their management.

Treatment options for the management of anemia in CKD:

  • Recombinant human ESA
  • Iron supplementation: Oral preferred, IV given only if GI intolerance to oral therapy.
  • Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation
  • Blood transfusion: Indicated only in severe anemia and failure to EPO therapy.

questions.text: A dead body is found at a crime scene. On examining it, you notice that fixation of hypostasis has already occurred. What is the minimum time required for this finding to occur?
questions.solution:
Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6 – 12 hours after death.

Purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to collection of blood in toneless capillaries in dependant parts of the body. It is called postmortem hypostasis/ postmortem staining/ postmortem lividity/ livor mortis/ suggilation/ vibices.

Timing of development of postmortem hypostasis:

  • Mottled patches – 1-3 hours following the death
  • Uniform area of staining – 3-6 hours following death
  • Fully developed and fixation of hypostasis – 6-12 hours

questions.text: A patient comes to you with a history of unprotected sex  96 hours ago. Which of the following emergency contraceptives can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Since the patient had unprotected sex 96 hours ago, an intrauterine contraceptive device(IUCD) can be used for emergency contraception in this case. It can be inserted within 5 days of coitus as a method of emergency contraception. All other methods of emergency contraception mentioned above need to be administered within 72 hours.

The administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy is known as the emergency contraception method. They are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse.

IUCD (Intrauterine contraceptive device) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium so that the fertilized egg is unable to implant. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week
